moves.1. e4 c6 2. d4 d5 3. Nc3 dxe4 4. Nxe4: The standard position of the Caro-Kann. Black has a number of playable options.
moves.4... Nf6: Horatio Caro and Marcus Kann would be pleased. This was their way of attacking White's centarlized Knight -- certainly the most direct method to challege the horseman.
moves.5. Bd3: Against a fellow master, Koltanowski -- and most modern grandmasters -- would undoubtedly play 5 NxN, inflicting a weakness in the Black Pawn structure. Against a mere amateur, however, he elects to retain the central tension.
moves.5... Qxd4 6. Nf3: Developing with tempo, attacking the Q.
moves.6... Qd8 7. Qe2 Bf5: Threatening to drain off all the White attacking power with 8... NxN 9 BxN BxB 10 QxB, and thus forcing White's hand.
moves.8. Nxf6+: Initiating the attack and weakening the Black K-side.
moves.8... gxf6: Forced, as the KP is pinned.
moves.9. Bxf5: Leaving Black no alternative if he doesn't want to be down a piece.
moves.9... Qa5+: The only way to regain the piece.
moves.10. Bd2: Clearing the way for his next move.
moves.10... Qxf5: The only piece Black has in play is his Q. He must immediately try to find a haven for his King and get his pieces activated.
moves.11. O-O-O: Seizing the open file with his Rook. Black's best course of action is probably 11... N-Q2 followed by 12... O-O-O.
moves.11... Qe6: Instead, Black gets greedy. He thinks he's forcing Koltanowski to exchange Queens or lose another Pawn.
moves.12... Qxa2: Black's fatal error. 12... N-Q2 was still probably best, to be followed by 13... O-O-O.
moves.14... Kc8: 14... K-K1 is answered the same way.
